acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.001mg/L of the crustacea (Marsupenaeus Japonicus) (ECETOC TR91, 2003).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 140mg/kg (EHC 200 (1998)).

carcinogenicity.rationale:
No data available
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID850, Copper, CAS: 7440-50-8."

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and it was a metallic compound, and since an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ/somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ/somatic cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and no strong positive data on mutagenicity tests in vitro (with some negative results), described in EHC 200 (1998) and ATSDR (2004).
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID850, Copper, CAS: 7440-50-8."

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: No data available, though being inorganic compounds containing chlorine. Classified into Class 8 (UN#2802) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
No data on female reproductive toxicity were identified. However, the study results reported in EHC 200 (1998) suggest adverse effects on sperm production in males, though no information is provided for general toxicity.
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID850, Copper, CAS: 7440-50-8."

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "severe effects" from the rabbit eye irritation tests (HSDB (2005)), and the human evidence (EHC 200 (1998)): "Eye irritation was observed among workers occupationally exposed to copper dust." The substance is thus considered irritating to the eye (though the severity of the effects is unknown) and classified into 2A-2B. It should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in EHC 200 (1998) of the human health effects of copper (though no data are available on copper chloride per se): "These data provide suggestive evidence that copper may be irritative to the skin." The substance is thus considered a skin irritant (though the severity of the effects is unknown), and hence can be classified into Category 2 or 3. However, it should be placed in Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

skin_sensitizer.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
skin_sensitizer.rationale:
Based on the description in EHC 200 (1998) of the effects on human health: "Copper and its salts may induce allergic dermatitis. Clinical signs include smarting, reddening, swelling, formation of vesicles and pustules." Also due to the fact that copper is classified into "Skin Sensitizing Substance" by the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy, and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 2"* by the Japan Society for Occupational Health. These classifications, though not specifying copper chloride, seem to include copper compounds. Copper chloride, which is a copper compound, should thus cause skin sensitization. 
* There is a provision to the effect that "the category refers to the substance concerned and its compounds, but does not identify all substances causing respiratory/skin sensitization.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
No data available

The chronic toxicity of copper compounds manifest as "retching, abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal pain, vomiting and diarrhea" (EHC 200 (1998)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale:
No data available

The acute toxicity of copper compounds manifest as "vomiting, lethargy, acute hemolytic anemia, kidneys/liver damage, neurotoxicity, elevated blood pressure/respiratory rate, coma and death" (EHC 200 (1998)).
